Prasad announced his resignation in a letter to Loomer last week.

Prasad, a cardiologist and professor of epidemiology and biostatistics at the University of California San Francisco, was hired as FDA chief in April by Makary and Kennedy.

The reinstatement was reportedly the result of a dispute between Loomer and Sarepta Therapeutics, a biopharmaceutical company that makes treatments for rare diseases.

Loomer, who once held a congressional bid in Florida, is a member of Sarepta's board of directors and the company's spokesperson. She had criticized the FDA's recent approval of a new treatment for Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which affects children, as a "scam."

In his resignation letter, Prasad said he disagreed with Loomer's characterization of the approval process, adding that he would be unable to effectively communicate with her on the issue.

"I cannot in good conscience defend the decision on this basis. I also cannot in good conscience communicate with you about this issue," Prasad wrote. "It is a shame that you are unable to understand the complexity of the approval process. It is also a shame that you are unable to accept the fact that I disagree with you on this issue."

Published

Dec 13, 2021 at 09:57 AM EST

updated

Dec 14, 2021 at 12:00 PM EST

Pfizer's COVID-19 pill may have some serious interactions with other medications, experts are warning.

The Food and Drug Administration last week authorized Pfizer's Paxlovid pills for high-risk individuals, becoming the first pill to fight COVID-19 in the U.S.

But now, experts are cautioning that the medication may not be safe for everyone.

The pills should be monitored carefully by doctors and pharmacists for serious interactions with statins, blood thinners and antidepressants, according to a pharmaceutical scientist.

The Food and Drug Administration should add a black box warning about the interactions, the scientist, David Light, toldNBC News.

"The fact that the FDA didn't have that warning, that's kind of scary," Light, a professor at the University of Waterloo in Canada, said. "The FDA's kind of dropped the ball on this one."

The FDA said in a statement that it's working to create a website to help doctors and patients determine whether certain medicines can be taken with Paxlovid.

"The FDA has not received any reports of adverse events associated with Paxlovid," the statement said.

Paxlovid is a combination of two drugs, nirmatrelvir and ritonavir. The nirmatrelvir works by blocking a protein in the body that allows the coronavirus to multiply. The ritonavir slows the breakdown of nirmatrelvir so it remains in the body longer and is more effective.

Pfizer tested the drugs together in a clinical trial of more than 2,200 people, finding that the drug reduced hospitalizations and deaths by 89 percent in high-risk individuals.

Paxlovid has been approved for use in 33 other countries. But the FDA said it required additional data on the drug's safety before it could be authorized in the U.S.

The decision clears the way for a quick distribution of the shots, which would be administered six months after the second dose.

The FDA authorized the Pfizer-BioNTech booster shots for those who have received the full two-dose regimen.

The agency's decision came after an advisory committee to the FDA voted unanimously against approving a third shot for the general public on Friday.

The 17 members of the panel voted that the available data did not show a need for boosters in people who are fully vaccinated.

They did say, however, that boosters should be available to people who are immunocompromised.

The committee members said the current evidence does not show that the vaccine's protection against the coronavirus wanes over time.

The panel recommended that a third shot be given to people who are immunocompromised, including those who have cancer, have had an organ transplant, are on immunosuppressive medications, or have uncontrolled HIV.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which was scheduled to meet on Thursday to discuss boosters, now has the green light to start distributing the shots.

The CDC's decision is not binding, but the agency usually follows the FDA's recommendations.

A senior FDA official said the agency will work with the CDC to decide which groups should get the booster shots.

U.S. employers added 216,000 jobs in December and the unemployment rate held steady at 3.7%, the Labor Department said Friday.

Economists polled by Dow Jones had expected the economy to add 165,000 jobs last month.

Average hourly earnings grew by 0.3% for the month, less than the 0.4% estimate, but more than the 0.2% increase in November. Over the past 12 months, wages have increased 4.6%, the same as November.

The Labor Department said the leisure and hospitality sector led the job gains in December with 67,000 jobs. Government jobs were up 52,000, and health care added 38,000 jobs.

The labor force participation rate fell to 62.5% from 62.8% in November. The participation rate was 62.4% a year ago.

The labor force participation rate reflects the share of working-age Americans who are either employed or are actively seeking a job.

The employment report comes a day before the Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point. The central bank will also release its latest policy statement, along with updated economic projections from each of its members.

The U.S. job market has been a bright spot amid a slowing economy and elevated inflation. Economists and Fed officials have said the labor market remains resilient even in the face of higher interest rates, stubborn inflation and other economic uncertainties.

The unemployment rate remained below the key 4% threshold that Fed officials have cited as signaling that the labor market is in a good place and that interest rates can be raised without causing too much damage to the economy.
